DOC.HEAD: Stocks Post Small Gain
Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT Amex close and change.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market struggled to a small gain Thursday, halting a week-long slide. Analysts said traders drew some mild encouragement from signs that the Federal Reserve was continuing little by little to relax its credit policy. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 73.16 points in the five preceding sessions, gained 3.20 to 2,691.13. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 932 up, 627 down and 460 unchanged. With five trading days left in 1989, the Dow Jones industrial average shows a net gain of 522.56 points, or 24.1 percent, since the start of the year. Analysts said evidence of a new move Wednesday toward easier credit by the Federal Reserve encouraged buyers to nibble warily at stocks that have lately suffered from worries about a possible recession in 1990. Brokers also said traders remained hopeful that stock prices might benefit from the so-called January effect, a historical tendency for the market _ and especially smaller stocks _ to show greater-than-usual strength in the first few weeks of a new year. One explanation often offered for the January effect is the lifting of yearend selling pressures from investing institutions cleaning losers out of their portfolios and individual investors realizing losses for tax purposes. Stride Rite jumped 3] to 27~. Late Wednesday an investor group proposed a bid for the company at $32 a share. Among recently depressed stocks, Walt Disney rose 2\ to 114\; Federal National Mortgage [ to 34{; General Motors ~ to 42], and International Business Machines { to 95[. Boston Edison dropped 1{ to 20[. The company cut its quarterly dividend from 45.5 cents to 38 cents a share. Caterpillar, which projected a decline in fourth-quarter earnings from the previous three months, fell 1~ to 57|. Magnetek lost 1 to 8| in one of the day's biggest percentage declines. The company said a jury ruled against its Universal Manufacturing subsidiary in a breach-of-contract case involving L.M.P. Corp. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 175.15 million shares, against 176.52 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 212.70 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $18.18 billion, or 0.55 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained .96 to 190.50. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 1.95 to 393.81, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 1.94 at 344.78. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market climbed 4.15 to 441.14. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 369.55, up 1.37.
